Title: Ubisoft reportedly killed an Assassin's Creed game about fighting the Klan for being too "political"
Description:
Sitting, as they do, at the intersection between “actual human history” and “stabbing the shit out of a ton of powerful dickheads,” Ubisoft's Assassin's Creed games have always been inherently political, pretty much by default. It's built right there into the concept, after all, even before you get into games that specifically deal with topics like slavery, political revolutions, or racially motivated villains: These are games about assassins, who tend, as a rule, to target people insulated and protected by the societal structures they exist within. Hard to make that entirely apolitical.

But dang if folks won't try, as a new report from former Kotaku editor in chief Stephen Totilo suggests today. Totilo was writing for his newsletter Game File, reporting that Ubisoft actually canceled an Assassin's Creed game last year, owing in large part to the current political climate in its target markets. For some reason, the company apparently thought it might have trouble selling an Assassin's Creed game about a freed slave sticking knives in the neck of members of the Ku Klux Klan in the midst of the Reconstruction South to Americans living in the middle of the 2020s. Weird, right?

According to anonymous sources who worked on the project, the untitled Assassin's Creed game would have taken place in America in the 1860s, touching briefly on the Civil War before mostly focusing on the post-war period, with its hero returning to the South to covertly battle forces of oppression and division. (Among other things, the game apparently intended to demonstrate how “racial tensions can be manipulated as a means to control a society.”) Although the Klan—founded in 1865 as a racist backlash against the end of slavery and the granting of the vote to Black men—wouldn't have been the game's only villain, it certainly sounds like our hero would have had to contend with its rise, presumably in knife-neck fashion.

The game was apparently in early development, having passed early stages of approval from higher-ups at the France-based company. (Developers were apparently excited, both by the unique setting, and the chance to say something meaningful with the game.) But then, in July of 2024, the verdict was handed down: The game was being canceled, reportedly over worries about political tensions in America, which eats a lot of Assassin's Creed games. To quote one unnamed developer, the game would have been “Too political in a country too unstable.”

There probably were other factors at play: Around this same time, Ubisoft was getting backlash from Online Gamer Types over announcing that its Japan-set Assassin's Creed: Shadows would feature a Black man, Yasuke, as one of its protagonists. Still, the insiders quoted in Totilo's newsletter emphasize that “anxiety over the political climate in the United States” was the major factor in not releasing the Reconstruction-focused game. Instead, Assassin's Creed—which previously covered the U.S. in two different games from 2012, and targeted the slave trade with 2013's Freedom Cry—is ditching North America entirely. The franchise's next game, codenamed Hexe, will reportedly focus on witch trials in the 16th century Holy Roman Empire.

Title: John Cena channels Peacemaker's heartbreak in a career-best performance
Description:
John Cena has spent most of Peacemaker‘s second season moping onscreen. His character, Chris Smith, a.k.a. Peacemaker, struggles with grief, loneliness, PTSD, heartbreak, and the constant threat of A.R.G.U.S.'s vengeance-seeking new leader, Rick Flag Sr. (Frank Grillo). Throughout all of this, Cena keeps his titular antihero's emotions and expressions restrained to convey Chris' agony as he seeks some semblance of joy. If only Emilia Harcourt (Jennifer Holland) would open up about her feelings for him, or he could join the Justice Gang and find his purpose. All hell finally breaks loose in the the season's penultimate half-hour, when Chris, to stop his friends from beating up a loved one, unleashes his long pent-up sentiments in one vicious, cathartic shriek and moment of self-reflection that—fair warning—will lead to surprising tears, thanks to Cena's commitment.  

This vulnerable version of Chris is miles away from the brutish antagonist introduced in James Gunn's 2021 film, The Suicide Squad. Even among a group of frenzied villains, Peacemaker's affinity for violence, crude humor, and betraying his teammates made him quite the foe. Cena, with his prolific wrestling career, turned out to be the right fit for a character defined by his machismo in the movie. While he wasn't given meaty material compared to co-stars like Idris Elba, David Dastmalchian, and Daniela Melchior, he brought an earnestness to make the guy who stabbed Rick Flag Jr. (Joel Kinnaman) just likable enough. And thankfully, writer-director James Gunn planted the seeds of Peacemaker's rich backstory, as he told Variety in an interview that year. DC's now-co-CEO continues to flesh this out in HBO Max's spirited spin-off series. 

The first season, which was released in 2022, unraveled Chris' turbulent upbringing under his toxic, white-supremacist dad, Auggie (Robert Patrick), and the lingering trauma of accidentally killing his younger brother as a child after being egged on by their pops. The show succeeded at blending this dark superhero fare with plenty of unabashed, loud comedy—a comfort zone for Cena in past efforts like Trainwreck, Playing With Fire, and the slept-on Blockers. In the gap between Peacemaker seasons, Cena sharpened those skills through a delightfully unhinged performance in 2024's Ricky Stanicky, and he even popped up in an episode of The Bear as a fast-talking Fak. But in its ongoing sophomore run,which wraps up October 9, Peacemaker is less about the punchlines—although those very much exist—and more about Chris' tendency to self-sabotage as a way to pay for past sins. The tonal shift allows Gunn to dig deeper into Chris' misery, and Cena sinks his teeth in to show off his dramatic chops in a way he hasn't gotten to do before. Clearly, this partnership with Gunn has worked out in his favor. (The director achieved a similar result with another wrestler-turned-actor, Dave Bautista, in Marvel's Guardians Of The Galaxy movies.) In Peacemaker season two, Chris seeks an escape from his nightmarish reality, where redemption seems impossible for him. So he decides to live in an alternate universe where Keith Smith (David Denman) and Auggie are alive at the cost of ignoring a brutal truth: The Nazis rule this realm. Chris conveniently misses a giant Hitler mural and the swastika on the American flag because he's overjoyed at spending time with his family and connecting with this dimension's Emilia. 

It's only when the 11th Street Kids—the OG Harcourt, Leota Adebayo (Danielle Brooks), Vigilante (Freddie Stroma), and John Economos (Steve Agee)—come to rescue him that he realizes the truth. In episode seven, “Like A Keith In The Night,” the group attempts to go back to their world when the Smiths confront Chris for killing his doppelganger. And when a revenge-fueled Keith attacks, the crew (including Eagly, of course) wastes no time thrashing him in a gutting confrontation that forces Chris to revisit the memory of his brother dying in his arms. Cue a guttural scream from Chris (“Get off him. What the fuck is wrong with all of us?”), followed by the tearful realization that he is the bad news in every world. As Peacemaker reaches his breaking point, Cena arrives at a new high, with a career-best performance that lets him check off that “make audiences cry” entry on his bucket list.

Title: Aziz Ansari defends performing in Riyadh as the comedy world debate rages on
Description:
George Clooney recently pointed out how ridiculous it is that the most trusted voices in media today are late night talk show hosts like Jimmy Kimmel. But Kimmel is one of the few to push back on his fellow comedians about performing at the Riyadh Comedy Festival in Saudi Arabia. (That's more than Conan O'Brien can say.) On Tuesday night, Kimmel hosted Aziz Ansari, and questioned his guest for joining the Riyadh lineup. 

“This is something that's become a big part of the news because people, a lot of comedians especially, are very upset, because the people who paid the comedians to come to this are not good people. It's a pretty brutal regime. They've done a lot of horrible, horrible things,” Kimmel said of the Saudi royal family, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. “People are questioning why you would go over there and take their money to perform in front of these people. I'm curious as to why you decided to do that.”

Ansari trotted out a now-familiar defense: “There's people over there that don't agree with the stuff that the government's doing, and to ascribe like the worst behavior of the government onto those people, that's not fair. Just like there's people in America that don't agree with the things the government is doing.” Kimmel—who has experienced the censorship of the U.S. government firsthand—pushed back, referencing the murder of reporter Jamal Khashoggi that was reportedly ordered by MBS. “I was just there to do a show for the people,” Ansari replied. “Whenever there's repressive societies like this, they try to keep things out—whether it's rock and roll music or blue jeans—because it makes people curious about outside ideas, outside values. And this is a very young country, like half the country is under the age of 25, and things can really change. And to me, a comedy festival felt like something that's pushing things to be more open and to push a dialogue.”

﻿

Reaching the real Saudi people (while taking money directly from the Saudi government) is a reasoning that has been trotted out by many of the Riyadh Comedy Festival participants so far, including Jessica Kirson, Bill Burr, and headliner Louis C.K. “Allowing international performances in Saudi, especially comedy, subtly broadens what's thinkable and sayable in a society,” Omid Djalili, who also performed, argued in an op-ed for The Guardian. But “the paradox of Mohammed bin Salman's rule of Saudi Arabia is that you can liberalize up to the exact point that he allows, but no more, and you must never question how much or how little he has liberalized,” said The Atlantic‘s Helen Lewis, who attended the festival.

Given that the Riyadh Comedy Festival was arranged by the government, there's reasonable doubt that the audience was made up of the “regular” Saudi people who might be inspired by such “revolutionary” comedy. (Burr described at least a few audience members at Kirson's set as “diplomats.”) Human Rights Watch has said the whole event “whitewashes abuses” perpetrated by the government, a position reiterated by The Atlantic‘s Vivian Salama, who sees the festival (among other recent entertainment events under the auspices of Saudi Arabia's “Vision 2030” plan) as a way for the country to become known for something other than human rights violations. Meanwhile, scholar Andrew Leber suggests that the “driving forces” of the Riyadh Comedy Festival are domestic, rather than international. Leber points out that Mohammed bin Salman previously “noted that ‘good recreational and cultural opportunities' could compensate for lower per-capita incomes.” The festival does reflect an interest in Western culture from the Saudi people, but it also “reflects an effort by Saudi authorities to shape what Saudi citizens should want—anything other than a political voice or political causes.”

Like Clooney marveling over late night hosts replacing journalists in the cultural consciousness, Lewis returned from the Riyadh Comedy Festival questioning “why we've ceded this much moral authority” to comedians. Though other American entertainers have done Saudi events, none have caused so much community in-fighting as this has within comedy. Those like Ansari profess lofty goals of broadening the cultural horizons of a “repressive society,” yet agreed to a government-approved censorship list for a government-sanctioned pay check. You get the sense that any stage will do, so long as there's an audience and the money's good.

Title: The sworn nipple-fighters of the Parents Television Council have filed for bankruptcy
Description:
The human nipple has outlasted another of its staunchest foes today, as SFGate reports that the Parents Television and Media Council, a “watchdog” group that was once on the cutting edge of asking “Won't someone think of the children?” has now filed for bankruptcy. Indeed, the PTMC has fallen a long way from the halcyon days of 2004, when the group—having yet to modernize by adding this newfangled “media” to its name—claimed to have been one of the single biggest drivers of people complaining to the FCC about Janet Jackson's breast being (mostly) exposed for (nearly) one entire second to Super Bowl viewers, an incident it straight-facedly called “an insult to every parent, every woman, and every child in America.”

Founded in 1995, the PTMC was the brainchild of L. Brent Bozell III, also founder of the still-running Media Research Center, a group that pushes narratives about left-wing bias in the media. (Would it shock you to know he's currently Donald Trump's nominee to be the American ambassador to South Africa?) Backed with the star power of an advisory board absolutely stacked with your great-grandparents' least problematic faves, the PTMC spend thirty years complaining about any American TV that even remotely smacked of being sexually explicit or otherwise inappropriate by their standards. (Looking at you, Spin City.) They complained that TV rating guidelines weren't strict enough. They went aggressively after guys like Seth MacFarlane, who once called getting letters from them like “getting hate mail from Hitler.” (Although MacFarlane later softened on the group, even conceding they might have a point about the number of jokes Family Guy deployed around sexual assault.) The PTMC even managed to modernize just enough to complain about YouTube—whose own prominence was famously also an unintended consequence of “Nipplegate”—and its willingness to run uncensored versions of Saturday Night Live‘s “Dick In The Box.” (Wait, can you write a whole history of American censorship at the turn of the century by charting viral Justin Timberlake moments? Someone should look into that.)

But the group lost its luster in the 2010s and beyond: Accusations of financial impropriety began circulating, and the organization was forced to subsist on such baby food outrage as getting mad at a TV show that had already self-censored itself as $hi! My Dad Says. The outrage surrounding Netflix film Cuties gave the group one last spasm of anger to coast off of, but, according to SFGate, they finally threw in the towel and declared bankruptcy on October 3. The group's final missive, penned back in early September, suggests that even broken clocks that are really fixated on kids hearing swears can be in the right every once in a while, calling on Congress to do more to regulate tech companies who are peddling artificial intelligence chatbots to children.

Title: Maria Shriver Bravely Shares Her Loss With a Heartbreaking Tribute
Description:
Joan B. Kennedy, the ex-wife of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, has died. She passed away on Wednesday, October 8,” ABC News reports. She was 89. 

Joan led an interesting life as a mother, a model, and a pianist. Many will miss her, including her niece, Maria Shriver (she is also the ex-wife of Arnold Schwarzenegger and mother to their four children). Shriver penned a beautiful tribute in honor of her aunt.

A post shared by Maria Shriver (@mariashriver)

Joan married Ted in 1958 and had three children. She is survived by two of them after their daughter, Kara Kennedy, died on September 16, 2011. She was 51.

Shriver posted a throwback photo of Joan on Instagram on October 8. The black and white image shows Joan smiling as she poses with her hands tucked into the pockets of her jacket. In the caption, Shriver paid tribute to a woman who left a lasting impact on her. She also gave a glimpse into her life.

“My aunt, Joan Kennedy, mom to my cousins, Teddy and Patrick Kennedy, passed away this morning,” Shriver wrote. “Not only was she a mom, but she was a grandmother too. She was an accomplished pianist, an arts advocate, and a beautiful soul. She valiantly shared her struggle with addiction so that others could share theirs. She courageously shared what it was like to lose a child, get divorced from a famous man, and carry on. Her life was challenging, but she persevered.”

Shriver also shared her own memory of Joan and how she respected her. “As a young girl, I marveled at her grace, her beauty, her elegance. As a woman, I respected her grit, her resilience, her perseverance,” she wrote. “May her journey be peaceful, and may her children and grandchildren know they did a great job caring for her, respecting her privacy, and loving her. Sending love to all of them.”

Shriver's fans have reacted to her tribute to her late aunt with an outpouring of love and condolences. 

“Maria you always have something nice to say! Bravo! So genuine,” a fan praised Shriver. “What a lovely tribute to your beautiful Aunt. May she rest in eternal peace,” another comment reads. 

Other reactions include, “What a gorgeous tribute for your beautiful Aunt. May she rest in peace,” “Or deepest condolences! Sending you much love,” and “Such a moving tribute. May her memory be a blessing. Love to you and the family.”

Title: One of America's Most Celebrated Chefs Passes Away at 43: Tributes Pour In
Description:
One of America's most admired chefs, Justin Woodward, has died at 43. The acclaimed culinary visionary, celebrated for his inventive approach to fine dining, passed away in San Diego, California, last Thursday from liver failure after a long battle with alcoholism.

According to The Oregonian, Woodward had been sober for three weeks and was just seven days away from receiving a liver transplant when he suffered a fatal internal bleed. He died surrounded by his family, who cared for him and showed him love in his final days.

A post shared by Johnny Phompadith (@hey.johnny)

Born in Boston, Woodward was remembered as a chef who expressed love through his craft. His family said he took “great pride” in every dish he created and left behind a legacy marked by creativity, generosity, and deep passion for his work.

A post shared by ok omens (@ok_omens)

Following the news of his passing, the team at Woodward's Portland restaurant, Ok Omens, paid tribute to him with a heartfelt post on Instagram. “His legacy lives on in their work — across the country, those he guided continue to thrive and push the boundaries of fine dining in America,” the post read.

For nearly 15 years, Woodward led the kitchens at Ok Omens and Castagna, helping shape both into defining fixtures of Portland's contemporary dining scene. Under his leadership, Castagna gained a reputation as one of the city's “most forward-thinking” restaurants, celebrated for its daring 20-course tasting menus and imaginative presentation.

Beyond his culinary achievements, Woodward was deeply committed to nurturing young talent. His former colleagues and protégés remember him as a generous mentor whose influence continues to ripple through kitchens across the country.

A post shared by Justin Woodward (@woodwardjustin)

Woodward's passion for food began early. After studying culinary arts at the Art Institute of San Diego, he trained in kitchens across New York and Europe. While working at L'Auberge Del Mar in San Diego, he met Michelin-starred chef Matt Lightner, who later brought him to Portland to join Castagna as sous chef.

He eventually took over as executive chef, transforming the restaurant's reputation. Woodward earned multiple James Beard Foundation nominations, including Rising Star Chef in 2013 and Best Chef Northwest for four consecutive years starting in 2015.

After Castagna closed during the COVID-19 pandemic, he focused on Ok Omens, which went on to earn James Beard nominations for Outstanding Wine and Other Beverages in 2022 and 2023.

Beyond the kitchen, Woodward was known for his kindness and generosity. His sister, Rachel Ruiz, shared that he often showed up at people's homes to cook meals when they mentioned a dish they loved. “He used his food and kitchen skills to bring joy to people, especially in their times of need,” she said.

Despite his success, Woodward struggled privately with alcohol addiction. “My brother struggled with alcohol issues in the industry,” Ruiz told The Oregonian. “We don't want people to speculate about his cause of death. We want people to know how serious alcohol can be and to get resources. Even if you don't feel like you're sick, it's doing damage to your body.”

The family hopes that by being open about his battle, they can help others seek support. “We hope Justin's sudden passing and our transparency about his disease will inspire others to get help when needed,” they said in a statement.

Woodward's life and work continue to inspire chefs nationwide, serving as a lasting reminder of creativity, compassion, and the power of food to bring people together.

Title: Beloved Rock Singer Passes Away in Tragic Car Crash Before Band's First US Tour Gig: Tributes Flood In
Description:
Rising rock star Ann Everton, best known as one half of the experimental rock duo Darsombra, has tragically passed away at the age of 43. Sun reported that the musician died in a multi-vehicle crash in upstate New York on October 3 while traveling with her husband and bandmate, Brian Daniloski, to the band's first U.S. tour show.

A post shared by Darsombra (@darsombra)

According to the New York State Police, the couple's van collided with a police car that had pulled over with its emergency lights flashing. As per Sun, Everton was pronounced dead at the scene. The state trooper conducting the traffic stop and Daniloski were taken to a nearby hospital for treatment.

A post shared by Carlos Guillen (@theexpandingman)

Daily Star reported that Jon Garrett, Everton's brother-in-law, confirmed the heartbreaking news, “On behalf of the Everton family, it is with deep sadness that I share the heartbreaking news that my sister-in-law, Ann Everton, passed away unexpectedly on Friday afternoon following a car accident.”

A post shared by MYRTLE (@myrtle.rhodeisland)

“She was an incredibly warm and generous soul,” Garrett said, remembering her as a “true artist” devoted to creativity in every form. “

She devoted her life to creativity—through her visual and video projects and through music as one half of Darsombra with her beloved husband, Brian. Together, they built a beautiful life, touring the world to share their art and nurturing a vibrant community of independent artists in their hometown of Baltimore.”

A post shared by Jon Garrett (@scrivenermgmt)

Nicole Evanshaw, Everton's sister-in-law, told CBS, “It's unfathomable what happened to them. Just the first day out, just on the way. She was vibrant, energetic, and creative. So creative.”

A post shared by Darsombra (@darsombra)

Everton and Daniloski spent nearly two decades together, both as a married couple and as creative collaborators. As Darsombra, they described themselves as a “trans-apocalyptic galaxy rock duo,” known for blending psychedelic soundscapes with multimedia visuals.

“They were a perfect fit for each other,” Evanshaw said, as per CBS. “They fed off each other's creativity. They were a partnership that so few people got to experience.”

Outside of music, the couple shared their passion for wellness as yoga instructors. They offered free community classes through Baltimore City Parks and Recreation, inspiring others to connect art, body, and spirit.

A post shared by Darsombra (@darsombra)

Everton's family has launched a fundraising page to support Daniloski's recovery following the crash. “We know Ann would have wanted nothing more than to ensure Brian is cared for during this difficult time,” Garrett said.

Messages of love and remembrance continue to flood social media. “I think her legacy lies in how she loved openly and freely,” Evanshaw said. “Her legacy is in her acceptance, the joy she brought, and the love she shared.”

The New York State Police confirmed the investigation into the crash remains ongoing.

Title: Teresa Giudice Ready to ‘Move On' From Joe & Melissa Gorga Drama: ‘Time Heals Always'
Description:
Teresa Giudice gave an update on her feud with her brother Joe and his wife Melissa Gorga—and it's a positive one. The “Real Housewives of New Jersey” spoke out in an October 2025 interview with Page Six's Virtual Reali-Tea to hint that she is ready to squash the beef with her estranged sibling more than three years after he skipped her wedding to Luis Ruelas.

“Time heals always — because then you forget,” Giudice told the outlet. “ Like, you're angry when it first happens. But now, it's been … I'm married three years. So it's been three years. He didn't come to my wedding, so we haven't spoken in three years.”

Giudice added that she doesn't want to talk about the past with her only sibling.

“You can't talk about the past,” the RHONJ OG explained. “Like, you really can't because if you talk about the past you're never going to really get anywhere.  I would say just to move on because I think that you'll never get anywhere speaking about the past.”

Giudice has gone on record several times saying she would never reconcile with her brother after their relationship issues came to a head while filming RHONJ season 13.

At the RHONJ Season 13 reunion in 2023, Giudice said her brother and sister-in-law would be out of her life for good after filming wrapped, per BravoTV.com. The two women refused to film together the following season but ended up in a blowout during the finale.

In a July 2024 interview on Kelly Ripa's “Let's Talk Off Camera” podcast, Giudice vowed to “never again” film on the Bravo reality show with the Gorgas. She later told PIX11's “New York Living” that the break from her family members was “a permanent break.”

In 2024, Giudice said on her “Turning the Tables”  podcast that there was zero chance of a reconciliation with her brother or sister-in-law. “We're done, we're done. We're never making up. That's never going to happen,” she said. “And I mean, [Joe] made his bed, he can lay in it now.”

She added that not even a “good payday” would be enough to fix the relationship.

But more recently, her stance has softened. During a Sept. 11, 2025 appearance on SiriusXM's Jeff Lewis Live, Giudice hinted that she could possibly co-exist with the Gorgas. “I mean, never say never,” Giudice told host Jeff Lewis.

After Lewis suggested that the feuding family members could “start a new relationship” instead of talking about their old one, Giudice agreed. “I mean, I guess we would, you know, have to see,” she said. “Yeah, obviously. That's the thing. You can't talk about the past. We'll see what happens. … you just have to kind of let it go and move on.”

Melissa Gorga appeared taken aback by her sister-on-law's recent change of tune. In a sitdown with Page Six on Sept. 17, Gorga said, “The truth is, for the last year, the door has been closed. [Giudice] has said out loud on multiple platforms, podcasts, whatever it might be, that the door is closed. So, the truth is, I'm just confused why it might be opening or cracking a little bit.”

“Neither of us have had any contact in probably two years at this point, so that's just so strange to come out with that out of nowhere,” the Envy boutique owner added.

Giudice's comments come as casting for RHONJ Season 15 remains in limbo. There have been rumors that Melissa Gorga recently test-filmed with potential new RHONJ cast members. Gorga refused to “confirm or deny” the casting buzz to Page Six and added, “The truth is, they're figuring it out. I know you don't want to hear this, none of us wants to hear this. I wish I had better answers for you. But they're figuring it out.”

Teresa just wants her paycheck back. Once a contract is signed it would the same old toxic bs. Thanks but no thanks. Let her find another occupation she threw that one away. Thinking she was irreplaceable, no one is! A hard lesson to learn!

Title: ‘Murder in a Small Town' Dedicates Episode to Late Star Malcolm-Jamal Warner
Description:
On Tuesday, October 7, viewers who tuned into the FOX series “Murder in a Small Town” watched the late Malcolm-Jamal Warner in his final performance before his death. The beloved actor, who was best known to many as Theo Huxtable on “The Cosby Show,” passed away in July after getting caught in an ocean current. 

After his death, showrunner Ian Weir commented on his excitement about working with him. “We were really delighted when Malcolm agreed to join us as a guest star — and completely thrilled by the experience of working with him,” he told People. “He was such a leader and a gentleman. It's such a terrible, tragic loss.”

At the end of the episode is a touching message: “Dedicated to the memory of Malcolm-Jamal Warner.”

The episode is titled “Mother Love,” and is the third episode of Season 2. Warner plays a father named Richard Bannister, who is fiercely protective of his teen daughter. Shortly after his ex-wife comes into town after a five-year absence, she's found murdered. Bannister ends up as the primary suspect. Many other characters and subplots were unfolding during the episode, but Warner made it feel like he was in a starring role.

“He was so dynamic in the role,” producer Kim Roberts told TV Insider. “It was actually not meant to be a huge role, and he found a way of bringing that character to life beyond any of our expectations. And he had to walk a really fine line between protecting his daughter and making sure that she wasn't going to be further traumatized and being sympathetic.”

“And I think he did an amazing job at doing both — that is, that we really cared for him and understood the dilemma, while at the same time… [he was] someone who was definitely a suspect in the murder,” Roberts continued. “So we were thrilled to have him, and he was such a joy to work with as well.” 

I think he really touched all of the crew, just because he is genuinely the person that you see, like he's just so — was, unfortunately — just so full of life, so full of goodness, and said really, really positive things to everyone, and it's very sad,” co-producer, Tina Pehme added. “We're very lucky to have had him.”

While Warner was known for giving his all to his performances, he also gave everything to friends and family. After his passing, many people, both expected and unexpected, came forward to talk about how he had changed them. His publicist, Jordyn Palos, claimed that he was responsible for her career. Others, like Anthony Mackie, Viola Davis, and Keshia Knight Pulliam shared the impact he had on their lives.

Warner is survived by his wife, Tenisha, and daughter. He had protectively kept both out of the spotlight, but Tenisha broke her silence on Instagram two months after his death.

“Tomorrow marks our anniversary —and my heart is wide open,” she wrote.

“For the first time,I'm sharing a glimpse of the love that began it all.”

“I can still hear my husband's laugh,still feel the way he made room for every part of me —every tear, every dream.”

A post shared by River and Ember (@river.and.ember)

Title: Beloved Reality Show Family Asks for Prayers as Loved Ones Recover After Tragic Car Crash
Description:
The “Meet the Putmans” family is asking for continued prayers as they recover from the heartbreaking car accident that claimed the lives of three beloved relatives. “We wanted to share an update and continue asking for prayers for Noah, Gia, and our entire family,” the family wrote in a statement shared on their Growing Up Putmans Instagram page on October 8. 

A post shared by Growing Up Putman (@growingupputman)

“We can truly feel the power of your prayers and God's presence through every up and down. Please continue to keep the faith and keep praying for Noah, Gia, and our family as we walk this long road of healing.”

The family confirmed that 11-year-old Gia remains hospitalized following the September 26 crash in Michigan's Tuscola County. According to the Sheriff's Office, the accident occurred when a semi-truck failed to stop at a sign and collided with a Jeep carrying eight members of the Putman family.

A post shared by Growing Up Putman (@growingupputman)

The Putmans previously confirmed that Bill “Papa” Putman, his wife Barb “Neenee” Putman, and their daughter-in-law Megan Putman lost their lives in the tragic crash. Other family members were taken to nearby hospitals with serious injuries.

“Gia had a rough night; no one got much sleep. Her ICP and blood pressure were high and unstable for a while, but praise God, the doctors were able to get things under control,” the family shared. “She's doing better now, and they're focusing on keeping her stable and taking it one day at a time. They were also able to remove her chest tube today, which is such a blessing and another step forward.”

Blake, 37, and his daughters, Lulu, 13, and Alena, 11, have since been discharged from the hospital and are “doing well,” according to the update.

Blake and Megan's 15-year-old son, Noah, continues to make progress in his rehabilitation. “Noah is doing well in rehab and continuing to amaze us,” the family wrote. “He's been sleeping better, talking, eating, and moving around more each day.”

They added that his therapy sessions have been encouraging: “In occupational therapy today, he was walking back and forth and even bouncing a ball on the floor! His biggest area of recovery right now is cognitive therapy, but we know God is working and healing him in His perfect timing.”

The Putman family rose to fame in 2017 with their TLC series “Meet the Putmans,” which followed 25 relatives living under one roof in Michigan. They later revived the reality show on YouTube as “Growing Up Putman” in 2021, continuing to share family milestones and updates with fans.

A post shared by Growing Up Putman (@growingupputman)

Following the accident, the Tuscola County Sheriff's Office announced that the truck driver, Pavel B. Shchukin, faces eight charges, including three counts of moving violation causing death and five counts of serious injury.

Despite the heartbreak, the Putmans remain focused on faith and gratitude. “Thank you all for the continued prayers, love and support,” the family wrote in a September 28 post. “We feel your strength and faith surrounding us. Please keep lifting Noah and Gia up as they heal.”

Title: ‘Father Mother Sister Brother' Trailer: Jim Jarmusch Teams with Adam Driver and Cate Blanchett to Remind Us We Can't Choose Our Families
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Jim Jarmusch hasn't directed a feature film since the 2019 zombie satire “The Dead Don't Die,” but the auteur is returning to theaters this holiday season with another lo-fi anthology film that sees him assembling some of his favorite collaborators to tell three stories about adult children trying to connect with their aging parents. 

Jarmusch's latest film, “Father Mother Sister Brother” is a triptych of stories unfolding in New Jersey, Dublin, and Paris. It stars Adam Driver, Cate Blanchett, Tom Waits, Mayim Bialik, Charlotte Rampling, and Vicky Krieps. Jarmusch writes and directs, with his frequent collaborator Frederick Elmes sharing cinematography duties with “Only Lovers Left Alive” DP Yorick Le Saux. 

 








Related Stories ‘John Candy: I Like Me' Review: Colin Hanks' Documentary Offers a Warm but Overstuffed Tribute Daniel Day-Lewis Tells Martin Scorsese Why He Came Back to Acting for ‘Anemone' and His Son Ronan 

“Father Mother Sister Brother” premiered at the 2025 Venice International Film Festival, where IndieWire's Ryan Lattanzio praised it as yet another example of Jarmusch's ability to pack profound amounts of human emotion into quiet moments.

“In appearing to give you nothing, Jim Jarmusch‘s almost perversely downplayed trio of short stories ‘Father Mother Sister Brother' winds up giving you almost everything if you can tap into its cool vibrations,” Lattanzio wrote. “Packed into the film‘s triptych of globe-spanning episodes about estranged adult children and their late-in-life parents coming together again (at least geographically speaking, when not emotionally) is a profound appeal: If we as children don't bother to ask our parents questions, meet them halfway, why should they bother with us? If you felt not loved by your parents enough as a child or rejected by them as an adult, maybe that's because they felt you didn't need them anymore, and so resumed living their own lives. What if familial damage is too late to repair? Jarmusch would argue it's not, though with his hushedly sad new movie, he's not about to coax his characters along the psychoanalytic dotted line from childhood resentment to coughed-up, adult-age catharsis.”

 










Following its Venice premiere, “Father Mother Sister Brother” screened at the 2025 New York Film Festival and will next screen at AFI Fest in Los Angeles. 

A MUBI release, “Father Mother Sister Brother” opens in theaters on December 24. Watch the trailer below.

Title: 'If I Had Legs I'd Kick You': Rose Byrne, Mary Bronstein Break It Down
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Rose Byrne gives the performance of her career as a therapist and mother on a ledge in writer/director Mary Bronstein's astonishing emotional whirlwind of a movie “If I Had Legs I'd Kick You,” and it's a ledge her character Linda has taken herself to, content to admire the miserable view instead of bringing herself off it.

Rather than cope in conventionally healthy ways with her daughter's (Delaney Quinn) mysterious illness that requires a feeding tube, or the fact that her husband (Christian Slater) is MIA, or that there is a giant water-spewing hole that's opened up in her Montauk apartment ceiling that may be a metaphor for her own condition, Linda takes to cheap wine, weed, and the comfort of her own spiral. She's also a therapist whose own therapist (a deadpan Conan O'Brien) works in the same practice and is also her supervisor. And she's a mother who believes she was never meant to be one.

 








Related Stories A24 and Charli XCX Confirm Cast for ‘The Moment': Rachel Sennott and Alexander Skarsgård, Plus a 2026 Release ‘John Candy: I Like Me' Review: Colin Hanks' Documentary Offers a Warm but Overstuffed Tribute 

Throughout this tense, risibly funny, anxiety-addled movie, Linda tries to come up with solutions. But she's batted against by her own clients — including Danielle Macdonald, who is terminally afraid of accidentally killing her own newborn child — and the medical administration hovering around her daughter, demanding immediate improvements or else. 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






There are also the unhelpful phone calls from her husband, telling her to enjoy the spoils of the crummy motel she's forced to reside in due to said hole. Couldn't she just enjoy a margarita by the pool for once? There's also a fellow tenant (A$AP Rocky) at the motel whose elusive appearance and vague attempts to help her out seem to embody Linda's own white privilege, putting us in the realm of a symbolic dream movie.

The A24 release premiered at Sundance earlier this year, where viewers were rocked and shocked by Bronstein's hilarious and abrasive house-of-horrors vision of motherhood. Linda's child is unnamed, and the young actress Quinn is kept offscreen almost entirely, with the 35mm camera's focus (courtesy DP Christopher Messina) instead on Byrne's ever-contorting face, on her inappropriate reactions to her own self-perpetuated catastrophes.

Byrne's turn is among the year's most potent, with the gift for comedy she displayed in “Bridesmaids” and “Spy” matched to the gut-churning dramatic gravitas of something like her ingenue lawyer in the aughts FX series “Damages,” opposite Glenn Close. It goes without saying that you have never seen the Australian actress in this register, and she more than delivers in a spectacularly frenzied performance that, if it's not Oscar-nominated by January, must mean that the whole Academy system is broken.

 










Bronstein, who is married to “Uncut Gems” co-writer and co-editor Ronald Bronstein, last directed 2008's mumblecore “Yeast” and has since kicked around as an actress on film and TV (including in this film as a stony therapist and nurse practitioner). She comes to “If I Had Legs I'd Kick You” with a Masters degree in psychology, which makes this film's pointed perspective on therapy's helpfulness or unhelpfulness especially, uniquely specific. 

She also wrote the film, which shot on location in Montauk in summer 2023, based on a personal experience with ultra-pressurized maternalness she isn't keen to share. There's a brilliant scene in which Linda unspools a throwdown rant at O'Brien's character, begging him to help her but not willing to meet him halfway on the patient's couch. As Bronstein told audiences after the Sundance premiere, Linda is in a situation of “I need help, I need help, I need help, but please don't help me.“

A24 is entering “If I Had Legs I'd Kick You” into the Oscar race alongside films like Josh Safdie's “Marty Supreme” (which Ronald Bronstein co-wrote and produced) and Benny Safdie's “The Smashing Machine.” “If I Had Legs” may be an endurance test for some moviegoers, but as Mary Bronstein and Rose Byrne explained in conversations with IndieWire, this cathartic story of a woman trying, maybe, not to fix her life but to at least turn the page on her worst traumas was never intended to be universal or relatable to all.

 










“I have a theory that if something is for everybody, it's for nobody,” Bronstein told IndieWire. “Art, and even entertainment, is so subjective, should be subjective in its vision, that it can't possibly be for everybody. If you start trying to calculate that, you've already lost… The more specific something is in its point of view and its vision, and the character that you're meant to engulf yourself in, the more somebody can find themselves in it. I find that to be true as a viewer, and [with] the responses to this movie I'm getting, I think I'm right.” 

Bronstein added, “Which is why independent film needs to stay alive, and there needs to be theaters that play it, because a lot of studios do try to make mathematically calculated fare for people to consume, and what they don't get is that's not what people want… [This film] is a novelty for people. They're not presented with films like this, and people are hungry for it and want it, and I hope the industry catches up with that.”

The following interviews have been edited and condensed for clarity and length.

IndieWire: Rose, do you quibble with reactions suggesting that you are making some kind of hairpin turn in your career here, that you weren't capable of something so dramatically charged before? It's a deeply intense film that demands a lot of you.
 










Rose Byrne: Mary puts it so beautifully. She's been introducing the film across these festivals and asking the audience to take a breath, sit in your seat, and think about the worst thing that's ever happened to you ever — the loss of a loved one, an animal, a job, the greatest trauma of your life — and then think about the worst thing that's happened to you today. Your coffee spilled on you, or the tin of your yogurt foil ripped off badly, and this film exists in both those sorts of places.

It's funny, this business, I have such an even-keeled approach at this point because I've been doing it for so long. I had never read a script like this. I have done a lot of drama and different genres, but this film really defies genre, it's sort of so punk rock. It has a lot of horror tropes and huge comedic set pieces that I think are very funny. That is really true. I've never had this experience in a film format, too.

Mary, why cast Rose Byrne? She's obviously displayed a profound range across drama and comedy, but there are other actresses you could imagine taking on the level of unhinged commitment this movie asks for. Yet you walk away feeling like only Rose could have played Linda.

Mary Bronstein: That's the answer. There are a lot of other actresses that certainly could have done it. It wouldn't have been exciting to me to utilize those actors, because I've seen them do it. I saw something in Rose where I knew I needed to utilize her comedic abilities. There's humor in this movie that is not easy to do for anybody, any performer. She got it immediately. It's a way of reintroducing a very familiar face to the world. “You know what she can do here. Guess what? She can do this, too, and she can do it better than anybody.”

 










That was exciting to me, and that's also why I cast some other untraditional people in these roles, like Conan and [A$AP] Rocky, where it's like, yeah, there's other people. There's a more traditional way to cast those roles. But would the movie have been as exciting? It's giving the viewer new context.

Rose, you've said you were surprised at first once the cameras started rolling how close they were getting to you, to your face, especially in the film's most dramatic scenes.

Byrne: The first day was the only time. After that, it was not a problem. I understood, but the camera got closer and closer. It's film camera. There are no long lenses. I did say, “Are you going to get that close?” Mary Bronstein was like, “Yes, we are,” and I never asked again. What I wanted after that was more information. I ask more questions than less. We had so much time beforehand that when we got to set — and it's an indie movie — we really could just jump off because we had rehearsal just the two of us, five or six weeks just talking.

Rose, Conan O'Brien said at Sundance that he was surprised you were not hospitalized, at least for dehydration, from this production. What did you do to maintain the stamina?

Byrne: That's so dramatic! [Laughs] There is a stamina to it, absolutely. Everyone has different practices, whatever, with spiritual practices or the way they eat or think. Of course, there is a stamina to it when you're doing a long shoot, whether it's this or “Platonic” or whatever. But my adrenaline was so high doing this film. It really was at cranked up because she's in every scene. The tension of the character, the huge failures that are constantly [thrown at her], she's constantly kind of acting out [as the film is] tracking her devolving as she's using substances and drinking. It becomes very technical with the hair and makeup department, just making that very, very clear. My adrenaline was at an all-time high, absolutely.

 










There's a scene in which Linda breaks down to her therapist over how she feels she was never meant to be a mother. This sets in motion the chain of events that gets her over her fears, her anguish. They end up separating as patient and client. What was it like shooting that scene?

Bronstein: I always referred to that scene as the breakup scene. So in a regular movie — not a regular movie, but in a “traditional” movie — there's some sort of love story. I don't have that in my movie. I'm not interested in that in this movie, or maybe in any movie… I'm very interested in platonic relationships and relationships that have boundaries and context, which a therapy-client relationship is ripe for. It is a breakup of a long-standing relationship. We don't know how long they've been in this entanglement, but we certainly know that we're coming in at the bitter end, and she is behaving very provocatively, but then also extremely honestly and vulnerably. That moment is perhaps the only moment in the whole movie where she's truly opened herself up, and what she is met with is a shut door, and that's it.

When I was filming that, it was so intense. It was so intense for Rose to perform that when I would call cut, she would burst into laughter, like uncontrollable, bodily falling-down laughter, and I think, as a release, because it was so intense, the performance. I was in the room. I try to be in the room when I'm directing, not down the hall at a monitor, because it's the only time that I can see these performances happen in front of my face. The rest of my life, I'll see it on a screen. I set up my shot, and then I watched them perform, and man, what those two did with that material in that scene is golden magic. But it was not easy. She's yelling in his face. And he is “boop” [mimics dead expression]. That's a testament to both of them as performers. It was maybe one of the highlights of the shoot, watching that.

 










Byrne: [Mary] was very clear in her role, and she has a deep understanding of therapy. We did talk to a therapist, and talked about therapy and all the different sorts of trappings of it, and what can happen, and transference, and all those sorts of concepts of what sort of personality types therapists can be. And this is unconventional, but I think you know that it's, it's, it's the love story of the film, it's the breakup, it's the end of that. And obviously, they don't have a physical relationship. It's not that. But that's kind of what it is for Linda, even though she can't acknowledge it.

Rose, did Mary's background as a therapist enhance the filmmaking in that scene, or others?

Byrne: Those scenes were very delicate, and very raw. For me, preparation is key, which is also kind of boring, but you never want to see someone's homework. That idea of those moments in therapy where you are at a breaking point, and what that looks like for her in this particular situation, and where it goes to next. Those scenes were pretty claustrophobic. It's one of those things where you know it's approaching, and you're like [deep breath] OK. That sense memory of “this is one that's approaching, and good lord, I hope it doesn't mess it up”… The comment on therapy is “this therapist who has a therapist who has a therapist who has a therapist who has a therapist,” is it like “The Wizard of Oz,” where you just eventually reach Oz, and that's the therapist? But it's just someone behind a screen.

 










This movie has been roundly compared to “Uncut Gems” in terms of delivering an adrenaline rush. Obviously, Mary, you have a personal relationship to that film. Do either of you find that comparison reductive or unhelpful, especially as that's a male-centered movie?

Byrne: Look, I love that film, and I love that performance [by Adam Sandler]. He brought that character to life which, I think, lends itself to his expansiveness as an actor and for an audience. But I digress. But to your point, I think that's flattering. I do think the films are very different. I do think the lens of “look, we've seen these films of a woman having a nervous breakdown,” that's not a new concept, we've seen that. But I've never seen it through the lens of a female writer/director to this extent, where it's really so purely from Linda's perspective, in a way that I think is completely original and unique. There's been very few directed by women. I should say, yeah, no, mainly men. If you think of the canon, you know the big ones that we would all refer to.

Bronstein: Look, I live in an apartment that I call “the house that ‘Uncut Gems' built.” That's why we live in this apartment. We were talking about it the other night. [The comparison] is reductive. That movie makes you have a certain feeling, which is anxiety and adrenaline… I don't feel the central feeling in this movie is anxiety. I think it's dread. Having said that, the way [“Uncut Gems”] propels itself forward is something Ronnie [Bronstein] and I have in common with visualizing storytelling. We met making his first movie, “Frownland.” He worked on my first movie, “Yeast.” He's become creative partners with Josh Safdie. I've gotten to do my other my own things. But that shared thing is there. We can't ignore it. But I do think it's reductive whenever I see it in print: “This is a Safdies movie, but for women.” I don't love that. Josh is part of my family, love him. Ronnie is my husband, love him. Nothing against them. But can we have a movie that's by a woman, that's about a woman that doesn't say “it's such and such, but for women”? I think we can.

 










One of the challenges is that there's no other movie, maybe, that one can compare it to. When Ronnie and I talked about it, that's kind of what we ended up with, is like, yeah, there's a shared language that we just have innately as partners, people that started off as creative partners, but then also, this movie is nothing like “Uncut Gems” at all. Even the character is not the same, and even the feeling is not the same. So it's sort of like, let's not do that. Let's let movies by women, about women, be that. [The comparison is] something I expected. Because, of course, these are people in my life, and Ronnie and Josh also produced the movie, and it makes sense, but let's let there be a movie that we don't say it's like this, but for women.

What I love about this movie is that it's not striving to be universally relatable. But it is a unique take on motherhood we haven't seen before, and integrated in the movie are news clippings of Andrea Yates, who was convicted of murdering her five children in 2001.

Byrne: The movie's really radical, and it's very punk rock, and it asks things of the audience about motherhood, which is very uncomfortable. There's a lot of shame around any disappointment a woman may feel or struggle or mental health issues, but it's sort of like a scream in the dark, I think. Linda is so disassociated from the experience that's happening to her. I don't think Linda can see her daughter until the very end. But I always felt the script had great symmetry in terms of reflection on that horrific case to her patient who goes missing, and she's stuck with the child, and yet can't see her own child in front of her, and the hole in the roof, the hole in [her child's] stomach.

 










Bernstein: There's been a lot of concentration on the themes about motherhood and parenthood. Those themes are definitely present in this movie. But since it is so specific, I think that rather than shutting somebody out that isn't a mother, isn't a parent, a parent isn't a caretaker, it invites them in as you're saying, “You're not Linda, you're not in the situation that she's in, and maybe you never will be.” But who hasn't felt like Linda feels, who hasn't felt like that as a human? Every human has their limits for how much they can take. I'm not religious, but there's this whole adage that “the universe won't give you more than you can handle.” That's not true in my experience. It will give you, sometimes, more than you can handle. And people have their limits, and people break, and they snap, and they can't take it anymore.

I would say it's a little even lazy that people are tying the movie so specifically to motherhood, because if you actually think about the movie, a very small percentage of mothers experience the type of motherhood that Linda's experiencing, which is being a mother to a sick child and being displaced from her home. That's not a typical mothering experience. Also in the movie, she does not mother. For me, the center of the movie is very much rooted in trauma and stress and that feeling of the universe piling on top of you.

 










Mary, back at Sundance, you were asked by an audience member about the meaning of the title. Are you still keeping its riddle close to your chest, or ready to talk about it more?

Bronstein: Whatever your idea is is correct. I can't speak for everybody's work, but there's a tradition of films and filmmakers where more questions are asked than answers are given in the work, and the movie is really asking you to engage with it on a very personal level. In my mind, no interpretation could be wrong, because how could it be? You're having the interpretation, and you're you.

What's very exciting to me is when people have come up to me with interpretations, not just on the title but some content of the film, that I never even thought of. As an artist, that's so exciting. I'm like, “Oh, OK, I could actually see that. That was never in my mind.” The title is the same thing. I'm a big poetry fan. Poems and lyrics and things and movies, they're not puzzles to decode. They're feelings, they're expressions, and you either understand it and it makes sense to you or it doesn't. If it doesn't, it's your choice whether you're going to spend time thinking about it.

I had a therapist that said one time to me — this was years ago, not my current therapist, there have been many therapists — when I was complaining, “Hey, how come when I'm so upset and frustrated that I'm not getting the support that I want?” And he said, “Well, nobody wants to hug a porcupine.” Linda is in the same situation, and when he said that to me, my response was, “But what if a porcupine needs a hug? It's not their fault that they have quills.” She's screaming for help, but at the same time, she knows who she is, and she doesn't want to change the parts of her that make it impossible to help her… She wants validation. She wants someone to be like, “You know what? This sucks, this really does suck. It's OK. You are angry, and that's appropriate for the situation,” instead of “calm down, let's chill out, let's be quiet.” She knows that in order to accept help, she's got to change.

 










A24 opens “If I Had Legs I'd Kick You” in theaters Friday, October 10.

Title: ‘The Chair Company' Review: Tim Robinson's Superb HBO Series Digs a Hilarious, Hypnotic Rabbit Hole
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

In 2025, Tim Robinson may be the only middle-aged white guy anyone actually wants to hear shouting. The former “SNL” writer and “Detroiters” star became an icon for the exasperated on “I Think You Should Leave,” a Netflix sketch series (co-created with longtime collaborator Zach Kanin) that summons huge laughs from a bizarro universe of semi-universal characters who are innately disagreeable, hopelessly confused, or reasonably vexed. Robinson plays many of these misunderstood or misunderstanding men, and the unassuming actor's bellowing exclamations — in response to losing his favorite TV show, holding people accountable, and banishing demonic intruders — often feel like the only method in which to properly process modern society.

 








Related Stories ‘John Candy: I Like Me' Review: Colin Hanks' Documentary Offers a Warm but Overstuffed Tribute ‘Death by Lightning' Trailer: Michael Shannon Is James Garfield, and Matthew Macfadyen His Killer, in Netflix Miniseries 

With “The Chair Company,” Robinson is still shouting, but he also distills many of his favorite, seemingly disparate traits into a single unified person. 

Ron Trosper is another frustrated, stupefied, and cantankerous everyman — someone who would spend his last dime at Dan Flashes or sneak into a lunch-hour meeting with a hot dog up his sleeve — but he's also judiciously relatable even when he's not embodying our collective fury. Met by a parade of crackpots whenever he flees the comforts of his core family, Ron's straining tether to the best version of himself is the source of anxiety-inducing suspense (lest it snaps) and the foundation of an HBO comedy that won't stop getting weirder. You care for Ron — enough to hope he escapes the rabbit hole he's dug for himself… and enough to hope he gets to the bottom, just so we can see it, too.

 










In a series about how easy it is to get lost when you're desperate to be seen, Ron is a middle-manager at a retail development firm named Fisher Robay. He's just been promoted — leading the design and construction of a shopping mall in Canton, Ohio — and his family couldn't be prouder. His wife, Barb (Lake Bell), daughter Natalie (Sophia Lillis), and son Seth (Will Price) take him out for dinner to celebrate, and Barb even offers a toast to her hubby's hard-earned success. 

Naturally, that's when the wheels start to fall off. 

In the moment, Barb's generous toast gets interrupted — notably, just before she transitions from admiring Ron's perseverance into highlighting his actual attributes — but the minor kerfuffle at dinner doubles as foreshadowing for the next day's big presentation at work, which climaxes with the series' inciting incident. Usually when a network claims a show's premise is also a spoiler, it's an annoying overreaction. But in this case it makes sense. They're protecting a damn good joke. So without tipping it, I'll just say the fuck-up is pitch-perfect: enough to push a certain someone over the edge, but not enough to warrant the ensuing insanity.

As a trade-off for withholding what some may view as a critical piece of information, HBO's poster for “The Chair Company” includes a key piece of text:  “There's a whole world under the surface, and only Ron has any idea about it. And sometimes the two worlds collide, and sometimes they don't. Ron holds them at arm's length from each other. Watch every week to find out when he can and when he can't.” 

 










The above may sound like bland nonsense, but Ron's mad scramble to keep his two worlds separate really does rest at the center of “The Chair Company.” In one hand, he holds everything a typical person values most: his family, his job, his security. They're on the surface world because they're easy to see. In the other hand, however, he holds his principles, his code, his basic understanding of how things are supposed to work. When those intangible standards are turned upside down, he delves into the other world, the one under the surface, searching for answers — mostly via the internet. Through his phone, Ron holds a portal into the unknown; a void filled with sporadic echoes and ostensible connections. Whenever he feels like he's found something real, it slips away, and he has to either let it go or keep chasing. And Ron is soon well beyond letting go.

“The Chair Company” could be seen as a loose story that exists to support a series of sketches. Scenes pivot between Ron's main arc and seemingly random side plots, each of which deliver quick bursts of outlandish comedy. (Virtually every time someone bursts into Ron's office, they're good for a hearty chuckle.) As with “I Think You Should Leave,” the humor is well-balanced. Sometimes we're nervously laughing at Ron, because he's done something beyond the pale. But just as frequently we're giddily laughing with Ron, because his befuddled indignation is so identifiable. Ron exists outside of our own sensibilities as often as he fits within them, and through it all, there's a depth to the man that's absent from many of Robinson's more temporary personas.

 










Take, for instance, a remark I initially read as sarcasm: when Natalie says her father is “so good at talking to people.” Given the awkward back-and-forths seen thus far and, even more so, Robinson's history playing poor communicators, the description is hard to believe. The guy typing “you're a fucker” into a customer service chatbot can't also be a great conversationalist, can he? But Ron really is good with people. Or he can be. When he's fully present, Ron can build rapport with his future father-in-law or rally the troops to buckle down at work. (He's the company spokesperson! Ron! Played by Tim Robinson!) He can be considerate and earnest. He can be loving and supportive. Seeing not just Ron's potential, but also the life he's already built helps us invest in his fate over an eight-episode season, just as it helps to draw us deeper into the mystery he's devoted to solving.

And if the personal hook doesn't grab ya, there's always the subjective interpretations of what is all means™️, which are so instinctively absorbed they tend to strike your funny bone before you even realize why you're doubled over. My favorite reading (through seven of the eight episodes) is that “The Chair Company” is about getting lost in an internet wormhole. Ron spends a lot of time bouncing around the web, fascinated and repulsed in equal measure. Paired with rapid editing that speeds up the experience to a barely intelligible rate, it's easy to see how Ron loses himself online and easy to feel like you're caught in the same vortex. Even when he touches grass, Ron's struggle still translates as one we all fight every day: when to log on vs. when to log off.

 










Then if your tastes skew toward current events, there's a conspiratorial bent to Ron's quest that, in a worst-case scenario, could end up with the father of two on a government watch list. If you prefer a surreal vision, there's a dreamlike quality to his adventures that repeatedly calls to mind “Twin Peaks.” Directed by Andrew DeYoung, who also helmed this year's Robinson-starring film, “Friendship,” the series is stocked in neutral suburban earth tones. Neither inviting nor off-putting, the backdrop stands in plain contrast to the dark and dirty corners of the world wide web he scrolls through, as well as the seedy spots in the real world where his online investigation leads him. There's no mistaking what's a mistake, and yet in a sea of beige, it's hard not to seek out even the most ominous oasis of color.

Still, beyond any one explanation, “The Chair Company” is broad and bizarre enough to embrace them all. Robinson, in spite of his well-earned reputation for playing loud jerks and dumb-dumbs, is a shrewd performer. His shouting is glorious for its unbridled force, but he measures the volume as meticulously as he doles out his decibels. For every explosion of irritations, there's an infusion of awareness, and Robinson excels at finding the perfect tenor, whether it's to heighten the comedy or ground the drama. Just as crucially, he's a great sad-sack. Robinson and Kanin found tender moments amid the chaos of “I Think You Should Leave,” and every so often they interrupt Ron's deranged dissent with a moving reminder of what's at stake.

 










For anyone who's seen “Detroiters,” that shouldn't be surprising. In Robinson and Kanin's short-lived Comedy Central series (co-created with Sam Richardson), the leads were two best friends who rarely caught a break, but they didn't care because they had each other, and they were doing what they love. In “The Chair Company,” Ron isn't doing what he loves to do, and he isn't holding onto anyone. Instead, he's going slowly insane, searching for a big break he's afraid already happened. Maybe it did, and he's too distracted to see it. Or maybe it didn't, and it's waiting for him at the end of his quest.

Holding both possibilities at once is enough to make you scream. Or maybe cry. But certainly, somehow, laugh.

“The Chair Company” premieres Sunday, October 12 at 10 p.m. ET on HBO.

Title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms' Teaser: Is ‘Game of Thrones' Durable?
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

HBO has released the first teaser trailer for “A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms” as part of the show's panel and festivities at New York Comic-Con. The “Game of Thrones” spinoff is based on George R.R. Martin‘s “Tales of Dunk and Egg” novel series, which is a kind of pocket universe within the larger “Thrones” mythos.

If that sounds like a “for diehards only” kind of adaptation, you wouldn't be wrong. And HBO is doing everything in this teaser trailer to emphasize the relatability and accessibility of this story. First off, they're telegraphing that the series, created by Ira Parker and Martin himself and starring Peter Claffey as Dunk and Dexter Sol Ansell as Egg, is as lore-free as possible. 

 








Related Stories ‘The Chair Company' Review: Tim Robinson's Superb HBO Series Digs a Hilarious, Hypnotic Rabbit Hole ‘Hamnet' Trailer: Jessie Buckley and Paul Mescal Fall in Love and Into Loss in the Fall's Most Devastating Movie 

You don't need to catch up by reading “Fire & Blood” or any of the main “A Song of Ice and Fire” books to “get” anything about this one. It's simply a character study, a relationship piece between the Dunk, a.k.a. Sir Duncan the Tall, and his squire Egg. It's a buddy comedy with a few dramatic notes that just happens to be set in Martin's medieval fantasy world. And fans of medieval fantasy worlds in general can see shades of the Arthurian legends here in the fact that Egg is secretly a prince.

 










There's also plenty of what “Game of Thrones” and “House of the Dragon” fans have come to expect of the series: stilted medieval dialogue, crude moments related to bodily functions (look at how that one guy hacks up a handful of spit), and liberal use of anachronistic profanity. When someone asks Dunk if he's Baelor Targaryen — a high role — and Dunk says no, the rude bastard says to him, “Then would you get the fook out of the way?”

Beyond that, though, there's a lot not shown here that one imagines would confuse newcomers, starting with the very concept of this show. It's set 100 years before “Game of Thrones” but about 100 years after “House of the Dragon,” right in the middle of both. It's a period of time that's totally been unexplored before now. 

But that may be a lot to untangle for fans of “Game of Thrones,” who expect that the Targaryen kings might have already fallen by this time (they haven't) or “House of the Dragon” fans who think that the conflict of that series — one Targaryen fighting another — is still going on. It isn't. In that regard, “A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms” kind of has the relationship of something like “Star Wars: Rebels” or “The Bad Batch” to that saga's original and prequel trilogies. Something that the already-converted will enjoy, but it may be harder to reach new audiences.

 










Watch the first teaser trailer for “A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms” below. 

“A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms” will premiere on HBO January 18.

Title: Daniel Day-Lewis Tells Martin Scorsese Why He Came Back to Acting for ‘Anemone' and His Son Ronan
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

It's not every day you get to watch Martin Scorsese interview a young filmmaker on his first film, from soup to nuts, along with his cast. 

In this case, after a celebrity-packed screening of New York Film Festival entry “Anemone” at the Whitby Hotel, Scorsese moderated a Q&A with Daniel Day-Lewis, who returned to acting after eight years retired to collaborate with his son, 27-year-old rookie filmmaker Ronan Day-Lewis, and Sean Bean, who delivers a remarkable, almost silent performance as Day-Lewis' brother.

In the audience were Rebecca Miller, who debuted her own doc series “Mr. Scorsese” (Apple TV+) at the festival, who cheered on her son and husband, as well as Paul Dano, Steve Buscemi, Julianne Moore, “Anemone” Plan B producers Dede Gardner and Jeremy Kleiner, and more.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories ‘Hamnet' Trailer: Jessie Buckley and Paul Mescal Fall in Love and Into Loss in the Fall's Most Devastating Movie Rose Byrne and Mary Bronstein Break Down ‘If I Had Legs I'd Kick You': The Title, ‘Uncut Gems' Comparisons, and the Film's Own Many Breakdowns 

What brought Day-Lewis back to acting? The chance to work with his son. They wrote during the pandemic, always in the same room, which meant there were substantial gaps between sessions. Day-Lewis often acted out dialogue, as speed typist Ronan took everything down on the computer. One memorable monologue — a gross revenge scenario against a pedophile priest — poured out of Day-Lewis. That's only one of many. 

 










There was some denial when they got started. “When we first decided that we would try to do this thing together, from my point of view, it was just the pure wish to work with Ronan,” said Daniel Day-Lewis. “We worked on a number of things over the years. From when he was the youngest age, we made stuff together, and it was a continuation of that spirit. Having decided to take that time away from movies, I knew that Ronan was going on to make films, and certainly, there was a sadness in me that I would then not have that chance to work with him.” 

The actor added, “So it began with this idea, just to be able to spend that time together. We were allowed to do it because we didn't know. When we entered into it, we had thought perhaps we could contain it in such a way that it'd be like a smaller experience that wouldn't necessarily involve the full weight of a production. But we were kidding ourselves a little bit with that, and certainly when we realized that we had something like a full-length script, it seemed like quite a big step forward, knowing that we were going back into the arena with this.”

It started as a simple two-hander between the two brothers, Ray (Day-Lewis) and Jem (Bean). “In the initial stages, when we were writing for maybe a year or so. It was just these two fellas in a shed, and we started to get quite stifled,” said Daniel Day-Lewis. “We've got to get out of this shed. We need to.” So they added to the brothers Jem's partner Nessa (Samantha Morton) and Ray's son Brian (Samuel Bottomley), who live in the suburbs, while Ray is hidden deep in the Northern England woods, off the grid.

 










Ronan Day-Lewis was able to decrease the anxiety of working with such seasoned pros because “we had written the script together,” he said. “It was a huge safety net on set, because we had discussed these scenes so in-depth that there was room for a lot more silence and trust.”

“But the point is, where do you put the camera as a first timer?” said Scorsese. 

The filmmaker relied on his experience as a painter. “The last few years before diving into this, I've been painting full time,” he said. “There were certain images that I've been obsessively drawn to through painting… certain reference images started to infiltrate the way I was thinking about composition.”

“Cinematically, it's very sophisticated,” said Scorsese, who proceeded to analyze the entire opening sequence of the film, shot by shot, including the sound design. Even though the two men start out with a prayer, “you just know they're going to battle… he's having his breakfast, and the sound does something, and the camera booms down, and you tilt to the sky and you feel this threatening storm which is approaching… That little magical thing between these two guys. And I don't know what to expect. You never know what to expect in the picture.”

“I did a lot of listening in this film,” said Bean. “It was so extraordinary some of the things that he was coming out with. I've not seen him for 20 years. He's crazy. It was a pleasure just to sit there and listen to this man. We spent some time in Ireland together. We didn't do a lot. We didn't rehearse or anything. We didn't really want to. We just wanted to see how it panned out and surprise each other on the day. The script was so good, it was so raw and pure. And it was about two men in their late 60s, which we are, they've been through a lot, and it was unapologetic. It didn't hold your hand for the audience. And it was a straight, raw story.”

 










Inevitably, the two men fight together, grappling on the ground and inflicting damage. “[He] resented me for coming and persuading me, so he had to hit me,” Bean said.

“Sean and myself and Ronan and Ben Fordesman, the DP, would, at the end of a working day, just rough out an idea of what we might start with,” said Daniel Day-Lewis, “so they'd know the lights, and then the next morning, we just crack on and just start shooting. And that's the way it went.” The shoot lasted 35 days in England and Wales.

Shooting in Wales meant the weather was always looming. “There's something about the landscape and the skies, the trees and the elements themselves seem to acknowledge the suffering,” said Scorsese. “They're part of the characters, in a way. It's as if there's something primordial about the whole thing, that kind of sanctity that's beyond Christianity, that's deeper, that just is there in the land.”

“Anemone” is now in theaters from Focus Features.
